questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ephesians 1:1-14 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'chosen before the foundation of the world', 'blessed be the God and Father', and 'sealed with the Holy Spirit'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'in Christ' throughout the passage
Pay attention to the emotional weight of being 'chosen' before time began
The phrase 'blessed be' sets a tone of worship and gratitude

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) is blessing believers, WHAT (spiritual blessings in Christ), WHERE (heavenly places), and WHY (to be holy and blameless before God).
tips: Include the concept of being 'chosen before the foundation of the world'
Note the sealing with the Holy Spirit as a key event
Mention the redemption through Christ's blood

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's election before time (v.4), redemption through Christ's blood (v.7), or the sealing with the Holy Spirit (v.13).
tips: The idea that we were chosen before the foundation of the world shows God's sovereignty and love
Redemption through Christ's blood is the means by which we are forgiven and reconciled to God
The Holy Spirit as a guarantee of our inheritance gives us assurance of what we will receive

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Ephesus about their spiritual blessings in Christ?
tips: Paul emphasizes that our identity and inheritance are rooted in God's eternal plan and Christ's work
This passage reveals that we are blessed in Christ by His grace, not by our own efforts
The main point is that we are secure in Christ's redemption and adoption

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of being 'chosen before the foundation of the world', the meaning of 'sealed with the Holy Spirit', or the nature of 'redemption through His blood'.
tips: Predestination (chosen before time) means God's eternal plan for believers, not human choice
Sealing with the Holy Spirit is a sign of God's ownership and the guarantee of our inheritance in Christ
Redemption through blood refers to Christ's atoning death on the cross, which reconciles us to God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of redemption through Christ's blood this week?
tips: Consider what you have been forgiven for and how that frees you from guilt
Pray for the Holy Spirit to seal you as you live in Christ
Practice living as holy and blameless as God intended by surrendering your sin

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the spiritual blessings in Christ and ask for the Holy Spirit to seal us as we live in faith.
tips: Thank God for choosing us before time began
Ask for the Holy Spirit to be your guarantee of inheritance
Pray for the church in Ephesus to be holy and blameless

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ephesians 2:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between being dead in sin and made alive in Christ.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'dead in trespasses and sins' (v.1) and 'made alive' (v.5)
Pay attention to the active verbs: 'made us alive', 'raised us up', 'seated us'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the church in Ephesus) is being described, WHAT (their state of being dead in sin and then made alive by God), WHERE (in Christ), and WHY (because of God's grace and love).
tips: Include the transition from being dead in trespasses (v.1-3) to being made alive by grace (v.4-5)
Note that they are now seated with Christ in heavenly places (v.6)
Emphasize that this is by grace through faith, not works (v.8-9)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the active grace of God making us alive (v.5), the breaking down of the wall of hostility (v.14), or the purpose of good works (v.10).
tips: The phrase 'made us alive together with Christ' (v.5) shows God's active work in bringing life where there was none
The image of Christ breaking down the wall (v.14) is a powerful symbol of reconciliation between Jews and Gentiles
Being 'created in Christ Jesus for good works' (v.10) gives a clear purpose for the church's life

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Ephesus through this passage?
tips: Paul emphasizes that the church is a new creation in Christ, united by grace and not by works
This passage addresses the church's past alienation and shows their new identity as fellow citizens with the saints
The theological significance is that Christ is the cornerstone of God's household and the source of peace

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The state of being 'dead in sin', the meaning of 'made alive by grace', and the concept of the 'dividing wall of hostility'.
tips: 'Dead in sin' (v.1) is a metaphor for spiritual separation from God, not literal death
'Made alive together with Christ' (v.5) refers to a spiritual resurrection in Christ, not physical rebirth
The 'dividing wall of hostility' (v.14) represents the barrier between Jews and Gentiles in the old covenant, which Christ broke down

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you live as a new creation in Christ this week?
tips: Reflect on what you were once dead in (sin) and how Christ has made you alive
Actively seek to be reconciled with others as Christ broke down the wall between Jews and Gentiles
Remember that you are created for good works that God has prepared for you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He made us alive in Christ when we were dead in sin. Ask for the strength to live as a new creation.
tips: Thank God for making you alive in Christ when you were dead in sin
Ask for the courage to live as a new creation with a purpose in Christ
Pray for unity in the church as Christ has broken down the wall between Jews and Gentiles

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ephesians 3:1-19 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'the mystery of the gospel' in verse 3 and the repetition of 'Christ' and 'Gentiles' throughout.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the mystery of the gospel' (v.3) appears as a key revelation
Pay attention to the phrase 'unsearchable riches of Christ' (v.8) which emphasizes God's depth of provision
The phrase 'Christ may dwell in their hearts through faith' (v.14) is a powerful promise of intimacy

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Paul is revealing, WHAT the mystery is, WHERE this revelation occurs, and WHY it matters to the church in Ephesus.
tips: Include Paul's role as a prisoner of Christ Jesus (v.1)
Note the revelation that Gentiles are fellow heirs and members of the same body (v.6)
Mention the purpose: to show the church the manifold wisdom of God (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the mystery of the gospel (v.3), the unsearchable riches of Christ (v.8), or Christ dwelling in hearts (v.14).
tips: The mystery of the gospel (v.3) reveals a hidden truth that was made known to Paul by revelation
The phrase 'unsearchable riches of Christ' (v.8) highlights the depth of God's provision beyond human understanding
The promise that 'Christ may dwell in their hearts through faith' (v.14) is a powerful assurance of intimate relationship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Ephesus through this passage?
tips: Paul emphasizes that the mystery of Christ's unity (Gentiles and Jews) is now revealed through the gospel
This passage shows that the church is the body where God's wisdom is made known to rulers and authorities in heaven
The purpose is to encourage the church to live in unity and to experience the fullness of God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'mystery' in Ephesians 3, the concept of 'fellow heirs', and the phrase 'manifold wisdom of God'.
tips: The term 'mystery' in this context refers to a truth that was hidden but now revealed (not a secret), as in the unity of the church
The 'fellow heirs' (v.6) means that both Jews and Gentiles share in the promise of salvation through Christ, which was not previously understood
The 'manifold wisdom of God' (v.10) means God's diverse ways of working through the church to bring glory to Himself

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'unsearchable riches of Christ' (v.8) this week?
tips: Share one thing about the unsearchable riches of Christ with someone who is struggling this week
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you understand how Christ's love surpasses knowledge (v.19)
Practice 'rising early' in obedience by seeking God's wisdom in your decisions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for revealing the mystery of the gospel and ask for the Holy Spirit to dwell in our hearts as Christ does.
tips: Thank God for the unity of the church in Christ and the revelation of the mystery
Ask for the courage to share the unsearchable riches of Christ with others
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help us experience Christ dwelling in our hearts through faith

chapters.chapterTitle: Unity in the Body of Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ephesians 4:1-16 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'one body, one Spirit, one Lord' and 'walk worthy of the calling'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'one' (one body, one Spirit, one Lord, one faith, one baptism, one God and Father of all) in verses 4:4-6
Pay attention to the contrast between the old self (v4:22) and the new self (v4:24)
The emotional tone shifts from urgent (v4:1) to hopeful (v4:13-16)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Paul is urging, WHAT they must do, WHERE this applies, and WHY it matters for the church.
tips: Include the church in Ephesus as the audience
Note the call to walk worthy of the calling (v4:1)
Describe the unity of the body of Christ (v4:4-6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the unity statements (v4:4-6), the call to put off the old self (v4:22), or the new self (v4:24)?
tips: The phrase 'one body, one Spirit, one Lord' (v4:4-6) is the core of the passage and shows the profound unity in Christ
The contrast between 'put off the old self' and 'put on the new self' (v4:22-24) highlights the transformative nature of being in Christ
The call to 'walk worthy of the calling' (v4:1) is a practical application of unity in daily life

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Ephesus through this passage?
tips: Paul emphasizes that unity in the body of Christ comes from the one Spirit and one Lord, not from human efforts
The main point is that the church must be transformed by the Spirit to live in unity and use their gifts to build up the body
This passage connects the unity of the church to the authority of Christ as head (v4:15-16)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'one body', the meaning of 'put off the old self', or the 'bond of peace'?
tips: 'One body' refers to the church as a single entity in Christ, not a physical gathering but a spiritual unity (Ephesians 1:22-23)
'Put off the old self' means to abandon sinful habits and attitudes that hinder unity (Ephesians 4:22-24)
'Bond of peace' is the unity that comes from Christ's work, which requires active effort to maintain (Ephesians 4:1)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, take one step to live in unity with another person by forgiving or reconciling.
tips: Identify a small conflict with someone and practice active listening
Ask for forgiveness if you have wronged someone, or offer forgiveness to someone who has wronged you
Focus on the unity of the body of Christ as the foundation for your actions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the church to be united in love and to live out the call to unity.
tips: Thank God for the unity that comes through Christ
Ask for the strength to forgive others as Christ forgave us
Pray for the church to be one body in the bond of peace

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ephesians 5:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between light and darkness and the call to walk in love.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'walk' (v.1, v.8, v.11)
Pay attention to the phrase 'children of light' (v.8) and the contrast with 'sons of darkness' (v.8)
Notice the marriage metaphor in verses 25-33 as a key illustration

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is called to walk in love, WHAT they are to do, WHERE this is happening (the church in Ephesus), and WHY (to reflect Christ's love).
tips: Include the three key elements: the church as a community of light, the call for husbands to love wives as Christ loves the church, and the warning against sexual immorality
Note the contrast between the light (v.8) and darkness (v.8) in the church
Describe the practical application: avoiding covetousness and impurity

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'walk as children of light' (v.8), 'husbands, love your wives as Christ loved the church' (v.25), or 'be filled with the Spirit' (v.18)?
tips: 'Walk as children of light' (v.8) - it's a call to active, visible living in Christ's light
The marriage metaphor (v.25-27) shows Christ's sacrificial love for the church
'Be filled with the Spirit' (v.18) is a practical command for daily life in the community

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Ephesus about living in love and light?
tips: Paul is calling the Ephesians to live as a community that reflects Christ's sacrificial love and the unity of the church
The main point is that the church must be a community of light (not darkness) that lives in love, holiness, and submission to Christ
This passage emphasizes the mystery of Christ and the church as a picture of divine love

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to avoid covetousness, the marriage metaphor, or the contrast between light and darkness?
tips: Covetousness (v.3) is a form of idolatry because it leads to worshiping material things rather than God
The marriage metaphor (v.25-33) is a profound mystery that applies to the entire church, not just marriage
The contrast between light and darkness (v.8) can be confusing because it's about the state of the church, not just individuals

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to walk in love and light this week? Focus on one specific area: e.g., your relationships or your attitudes toward wealth.
tips: This week, choose one area where you can be more like Christ in your love (e.g., how you treat your spouse or friends)
Practice being filled with the Spirit by singing and giving thanks (v.18) in your daily interactions
Avoid covetousness by focusing on what truly matters (like love and service)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about walking in love and light, as children of Christ.
tips: Thank God for Christ's sacrifice and the call to live in love
Ask for the strength to walk as children of light and to avoid the darkness of sin
Pray for the church to be united in love and to reflect Christ's sacrificial love

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Ephesians 6 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other
